summary: California Enacts Law Giving Consumers Ability to Universally Opt Out of Data Sharing (2 minute read) California Governor Gavin Newsom signed a law requiring browsers to make it easier for Californians to opt out of allowing third-party data sharing. Previously, this had to be done using third-party extensions.

summary: Scientists Discovered a New Creature That Exists Between Life and Not-Life (4 minute read) Sukunaarchaeum mirabile is a cellular entity that offloads certain biological functions onto hosts like a virus, but it also contains the necessary genes to create its own ribosomes and messenger RNA. Its discovery highlights the vast unexplored biological novelty within microbial interactions.

summary: Self Actualization (2 minute read) When Andrew Bosworth started Meta's Bootcamp program in 2008, he didn't teach the culture as it was: he taught it as he wished it were. New engineers didn't know the difference. The company grew fast, and within a year, more than half of the engineering team had learned about the culture from him. When onboarding in a high-growth organization, you aren't just teaching people how things work, you're deciding what kind of company they believe they've joined.

summary: HTML's Best Kept Secret: The output Tag (6 minute read) The often overlooked HTML `output` tag provides built-in assistive technology support for dynamic results. It can be used with or without a `form`, linking to input elements via the `for` attribute, and has great browser support.

summary: Extract_otp_secrets (GitHub Repo) Extract one time password (OTP) secrets from QR codes exported by two-factor authentication (2FA) apps such as "Google Authenticator". title: jwt-cli
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-13, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fmike-engel%2Fjwt-cli%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/01000199ddaf69cb-0003cc64-c599-4db8-96e2-fbaa39ccac9d-000000/zdFkRRJkTuj4zeIEerK7RWlQARawk85-WteN1U3cEVk=426
summary: jwt-cli (GitHub Repo) jwt-cli is a Rust-based command line utility that goes beyond basic JWT decoding by enabling encoding of custom JWTs with flexible header values, arbitrary JSON claim bodies, and custom secrets. Built in Rust for speed and portability across Windows, macOS, and Linux, it offers more flexibility than standard JWT tools. This makes it a practical tool for security testing and development workflows involving JWT authentication.

title: Spyware maker NSO Group confirms acquisition by US investors
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-13, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Ftechcrunch.com%2F2025%2F10%2F10%2Fspyware-maker-nso-group-confirms-acquisition-by-us-investors%2F%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/01000199ddaf69cb-0003cc64-c599-4db8-96e2-fbaa39ccac9d-000000/v3zL_hfOzjvvqLy0xeYHlpPDZFmvUHBjz3-x9C_wKJg=426
summary: Spyware maker NSO Group confirms acquisition by US investors (3 minute read) NSO Group, infamous for its powerful spyware, has just been taken over by a group of American investors. Even though new faces are in charge, the company's roots and oversight will stay in Israel. NSO's tools have targeted journalists and officials worldwide, so this takeover is making plenty of people nervous about what comes next and how these technologies might be used.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-14, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fkix.dev%2Ftwo-things-llm-coding-agents-are-still-bad-at%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199e267d218-3779c78d-8eba-471e-92b4-20c4b8a12ef4-000000/M1mxzN9gUwf0Gut4BiW6hUoIzBL-zrerpmIvokysNwQ=426
summary: Two things LLM coding agents are still bad at (2 minute read) LLM coding agents still feel awkward to work with due to two main issues: they don't copy-paste code like humans do (instead "remembering" and rewriting code from memory), and they're terrible at asking clarifying questions, preferring to make assumptions and brute-force solutions. These quirks make LLMs feel more like "weird, overconfident interns" rather than replacements for human developers.

title: “Depeg-gate” and the semantics of stablecoin stability
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-14, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthreadreaderapp.com%2Fthread%2F1977510426268029339.html%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/01000199e29d54cf-0e222999-6369-47b1-8bf3-104fdf647646-000000/VI3HjVs_hCpFQRZPxifxzHo_O3lRS77qc13G3V7HFMc=427
summary: “Depeg-gate” and the semantics of stablecoin stability (4 minute read) “Depeg” has become an overused, misleading label for any price dislocation, even when the stablecoin issuer isn't at fault. We should recognize the nuances between local depegs (venue-level liquidity or routing issues like USDe's recent event), widespread redemption stress (temporary withdrawal uncertainty like USDC during SVB), and collateral loss (true issuer failure like Terra/Luna). comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-14, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fcybersecuritynews.com%2Fedr-freeze-tool-technical-workings%2F%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/01000199e2d4c644-6fe25f09-9713-48f2-a393-f55760da966e-000000/6gvV4C6vk4biCEiwQA2Bc6zphVpDRPL5Lu_lKQ7yb2g=426
summary: EDR-Freeze Tool Technical Workings Along With Forensic Artifacts Revealed (3 minute read) EDR-Freeze is a Windows tool that temporarily disables EDR software without the need for a kernel driver. The tool exploits the Windows Error Reporting (WER) system to suspend all threads while it generates a process dump and then holds the dump in that state for a configurable period of time, effectively suspending the EDR. title: The False Consensus Effect
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-15, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fckarchive.com%2Fb%2F92uzhnh6z2wwvh3roomrdfzpxl933iwh2pxox%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/01000199e7d9e47e-7669cded-78cc-45ae-a405-d329ebdbc24f-000000/0PA4jgaCGgg_E5J0BTcM8_EtowQdzEw0Ng3tqny7xzY=427
summary: The False Consensus Effect (3 minute read) Marketers often assume customers think like they do – and pay for it. The “False Consensus Effect” explains why: we mistake our own tastes for the norm. Netflix proved the power of testing assumptions when it dropped House of Cards all at once and watched viewers binge six episodes in days. Amazon built its empire on A/B tests, not opinions. Sometimes you're not your customer, so stop building for yourself.

title: The Discomfort of Focus
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-15, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Freecegriffiths.substack.com%2Fp%2Fthe-discomfort-of-focus%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/01000199e7d9e47e-7669cded-78cc-45ae-a405-d329ebdbc24f-000000/O-4Q39jTr43s9i95Q3XtcEbxUtp1D8n6zIShNjHBycI=427
summary: The Discomfort of Focus (5 minute read) What if focus isn't about discipline but about trust, as in trusting that saying no won't close doors, it'll open the right ones faster. Most founders chase breadth to feel safe, but this team learned real momentum came from committing to one painfully specific ICP. The paradox was that narrowing created freedom. Once they stopped hedging and chose, everything else (clarity, conviction, growth) finally followed.

title: The Epidemic of Wasted Talent
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-15, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthestillwandering.substack.com%2Fp%2Fthe-epidemic-of-wasted-talent%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/01000199e7d9e47e-7669cded-78cc-45ae-a405-d329ebdbc24f-000000/TauuujtAPlEfWbouGxO2dSgs8BzzsuLHiguWHtNrmoo=427
summary: The Epidemic of Wasted Talent (5 minute read) Most jobs don't need you, they just need someone. Alex McCann argues that high salaries often mask a deeper cost: companies pay you to ignore your own potential. He contrasts corporate comfort with a Colombian birdwatcher who found purpose in work only he could do. The point isn't to quit tomorrow, but to start creating something that couldn't exist without you. Being replaceable pays well. Being irreplaceable matters more.

title: SimonMed Imaging: 1.27M Individuals Affected by January 2025 Cyberattack
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-15, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FqvoxH9/1/01000199e7fb2ed0-b2692e63-6f16-434f-8519-83edab2ce9b0-000000/km5PhCgMzlroOfTRsZaJ7w1nvnFkM0yYx_ZpG9sdNQw=427
summary: SimonMed Imaging: 1.27M Individuals Affected by January 2025 Cyberattack (3 minute read) In early 2025, a cyberattack at SimonMed Imaging exposed the data of over 1.27 million patients, including medical and personal information, with the ransomware group Medusa claiming responsibility. Medusa likely received a ransom to prevent data release. SimonMed responded with improved security measures and offered credit monitoring and identity theft protection to impacted people.

summary: Satellites found exposing unencrypted data, including phone calls and some military comms (1 minute read) Sensitive personal, corporate, and military data is being transmitted unencrypted via about half of Earth's geostationary satellites, according to researchers. Using a basic satellite receiver, they accessed voice calls, texts, and critical infrastructure communications, exposing serious privacy and security risks.

summary: Pixel-stealing “Pixnapping” attack targets Android devices (3 minute read) “Pixnapping” is an advanced attack where a malicious Android app can secretly steal individual pixels from your device's screen—enabling it to extract sensitive data like 2FA codes, even from supposedly secure apps. The attack exploits Android's app messaging system and nearly invisible overlays.

title: How Do Timing Attacks Work?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-15, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fnickg.ca%2F%23%2Fposts%2Ftiming-attacks%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/01000199e7fb2ed0-b2692e63-6f16-434f-8519-83edab2ce9b0-000000/dcayh-cWsR3TYBFCveTTn7uaRHGO92uvvOP_S1jBlic=427
summary: How Do Timing Attacks Work? (3 minute read) Timing attacks that target string comparison work by measuring how long it takes a vulnerable server to verify a string, such as a password or other secret. When a vulnerable function compares two strings, it loops through each character to check for equality, causing the function to take slightly longer to complete with each correct character. The page includes a demo for how this attack works in practice.
